ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: we were allowed to watch the lectures asynchronously and we had weekly discussion sections
the class also recorded the lectures in addition to providing a live virtual lecture.
Live lectures that were recorded as well as a weekly discussion section that was mandatory and not recorded
live lectures that were also recorded
live virtual lecture
live discussion section on zoom.
N/a
Recorded and Live
While the virtual lectures were live, they were also recorded so that students could listen to it after. This class also had a mandatory virtual discussion section.
Recorded lecture and live virtual lecture combination
The lectures were recorded so they could be watched live or at a later time.
virtual discussion sections
The live virtual lectures were also recorded for future reference, which I found to be very helpful.
Recorded lecture
live virtual and recorded
Live virtual lectures were recorded. There were also recorded review sessions (one on the practice exam and and one on general content) before each of our exams.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic chem introduction, learning how to learn big lecture style, really great teaching and studying skills
I developed a really good foundation in chemistry, and the class provided a comprehensive understanding of different chemistry topics
I learned introductory chemistry.
I learned a lot about basic chemistry and memorization.
I learned general chemistry.
I learned the basics of chemistry. I don't think I developed many new skills, but I have a better understanding of why some things happen in life.
Learned about chemistry
I learned the basics of General Chemistry 161.
Introduction to general chemistry principles which were then applied to scientific quantitative problems.
Critical thinking and analysis
I learned a lot about Chemistry
I learned how to stay focused in a virtual setting and stay engaged in a lecture style class. I also learned much about general chemistry beyond the scope of my high school course.
basic knowledge of chemistry
I learned the basics of general chemistry.
good knowledge of general chemistry

In terms of content, this course is essentially AP chemistry. It's important to do plenty of practice problems in this class because the practice exams do not resemble the actual exam (which I found annoying at first, but later I realized this helped me focus on understanding and applying concepts more effectively). I guess the insight I developed is that practice problems are always the way to go in chemistry.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Prof. Cooper is AMAZING! he is so patient, posts all the notes and lectures, and teaches in such an approachable, understanding and applicable way. 
He was so generous with the timing and pace of the class. 
The only challenging part was that the first discussion section did not get to learn what would be on the quiz before we had to submit our responses while the second discussion section had much more time to prepare and could learn the concepts with the class.

the practice exams did not really reflect the actual exams so it was quite difficult to feel properly prepared for the exams throughout the term. The modes of student support were definitely a strength. I was able to set up frequent meetings with the TA and felt very supported in that sense.

Strengths: The sapling psets that allowed you to see if you got your questions correct in real time. The zoom lectures were fantastic. 
Weaknesses: The fact that the grade cutoffs are unknown. I have not idea what my grade is. Also, the exams were often very very very time constrained which I feel was a bit unfair considering we were taking them via zoom on a piece a paper with the questions on our screen. I spent a lot of time copying down information from my screen onto my piece of paper in order to be able to start exam questions.
This course was very informative and offered good explanations of materials.

Strengths: instruction, learning curve assignments, recorded lecture
Weaknesses: testing manner
The exams tested the rapidity of regurgitation of material rather than an overall understanding. The testing manner could be improved by providing additional time during exams.
strengths: feedback on tests were prompt and discussion sections were dependent upon student questions

I was placed into a section designed for students underprepared in chemistry (small lecture, and our own TA, and different assignments and tests). I was happy to be in this course because I knew a lot less coming into chemistry than my friends in the other section. I thought a weakness was that we spent so long on the intro to the class. We spent 2 weeks on chapter 1, which was basically the only material I already knew coming into the class. That meant we had to speed up during the harder topics to get through all the material for the course, which compounded the difficulty of those topics.
There was also one week where the lab for that week had to do with topics we hadn't covered in lecture (I had the same lab as people in normal chem), which made doing the lab report difficult.
More time could be spent on the skills tested in the exam as opposed to less important details
I enjoyed the live lecture setting and the engaging discussion section. There was plenty of material to go over for problem sets and exams.

The strengths of this course was the variety of resources available to get help (Professor Cooper's office hours, TA office hours, peer tutoring). The weakness was the difficulty of timed midterm/final exams especially to people that have never taken chemistry courses before.

I thought that the way this course was organized (lecture, learning curves, problem sets, discussion sections) was a strength to the course because I had enough practice with the material before each midterm. However, I think that the quizzes before each discussion section did not add a lot to my learning. Often, they covered topics that I had to read ahead in the textbook to understand, and I think discussion section was more helpful to me when it was lead by student's questions and what they identified as their weaknesses.
More review sessions before tests

The greatest strength of the course was that the teacher was very organized and I knew what was expected of me and liked the learning curve aspect of my homework to help me prepare for what would be asked of me through practice that was graded on completion. I found that the quizzes before the sections to be the greatest weakness because they often tested the material we learned in the lecture that ended 15 minutes before the section and we were expected to complete these quizzes earlier when we had not yet learned everything necessary.
I found the sapling homework very helpful as a way of reviewing and practicing material.
I thought that the course was very well taught and explained in a way that made it very easy to understand all of the information.
Professor Cooper was a great lecturer. The way he taught made absorbing information very easy, and he was great at responding to questions so I was never afraid to ask.

Strengths: Paul Cooper is an amazing professor. He is extremely understanding to any difficulty you may be having, and he often uses analogies to explain difficult concepts well. I also enjoyed that all his presentation slides were posted prior to the start of the course; this made planning ahead easy for questions and note-taking.

Weaknesses: It's gen chem... the concepts are unfortunately pretty boring, and anything that is fun isn't explained because "you don't know enough for this yet."

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think for a lecture it translated fairly easily to an online format. It's just hard no matter what to always be as engaged when zooming into the class.
The lecture via Zoom was effective, but exams online were difficult to manage.
I really liked how the lectures were recorded. It would allow me to not feel as Zoom-fatigued as I could semi-listen to a lecture but really absorb it later when I watched the recording.
The recorded lectures were very useful because they allowed me to go back and work on things I was stuck on.
I'm not sure how this class was different due to covid. It was really helpful that lectures were recorded and posted online.
The lectures worked well online

The multiple zoom office hours and review sessions were great because I could always join a call if I had problems. The professors were very helpful and willing to answer questions whenever they were available.
I think that it was a smart decision to make the lectures recorded.
Online office hours with the TA was very helpful in clearing up confusing concepts.
Nothing, everything on zoom was great

The course succeeded in making help accessible and the smaller size class for the lecture made it easier to be engaged in the online setting. An improvement to the course would be more flexibility with section times.
I appreciated that lectures were recorded

I found that having the recorded lectures to look back on was very helpful, while it was nice to still have a live classroom setting where I could listen to the professor teach and ask any questions I had.

Recorded lectures are one of the best things to come out of this new virtual setting! I love being able to go back and rewatch lectures at 2x speed. Other things that I enjoyed were lecture materials being posted on Canvas. I didn't end up using the textbook as much as I should've, perhaps because it was digital, but I'm glad I was able to spend the hundred dollars or so I would've otherwise had to spend on it.

As for improvements, this course could use more interactive elements. Dr. Cooper (bless him) did his best to keep the class engaged by asking us questions during lecture, but it wasn't long before everyone's cameras were off and only one or two super dedicated students remained to answer him. Maybe some polls or whiteboard use during our virtual lectures could keep everyone more engaged?

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Especially with Prof. Cooper. Very manageable workload and I really enjoyed the class.
yes, I think this smaller section was nice to get a more student-focused experience in learning chemistry.
I would only ever recommend chemistry if its a prereq or if you truly love chemistry.
I recommend this course because it allows students to develop stem-based studying skills. It was also an extremely informative course.
Yes!
I would because of the small class size.

Intro chem is a prereq for a lot of other science classes (and premed of course). I think if you're potentially interested in those fields, you ought to take it (and it's not a bad prereq at allthis was a solid and pretty interesting class). I don't think it's worth taking just for fun (that's more or less the reason I took it this semester, and I probably won't be taking gen chem II next semester).
If you have to take it you probably should
For science or pre-med students.

Yes, I would recommend this course. It was great that the lecture only had 30 people because we were able to ask questions. Additionally, the professor provided lots of materials for exams and homework. There were practice exams posted and plenty of outside help.

I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in introductory chemistry classes. If you have little STEM experience, be prepared to put in hours to study and reinforce material.
Yes. Although I struggled in this class, I am proud of the progress I have made in understanding basic chemistry, and this could not have been possible without this structure of this course.
Yes, teaches the basic foundations of chemistry.

Yes, I would recommend this course to a student interested in being pre-med or becoming a chemistry major, but would not find it very helpful for a broader scope as the material is not applicable to many fields.
Yes, the material was interesting and presented well
I would definitely recommend this course to another student, as chemistry is a super useful class to take, and the the teaching staff of this course was excellent.
Yes, if you need an understanding of chemistry, this is the place to start. The course curriculum teaches a wide breadth of general chemistry concepts.

Take this course only if you're a premed student or you need it for your major. Gen chem is one of those intro STEM courses people take to get over with, not enjoy. (I'm so grateful for Dr. Cooper, though - he made this course a lot less boring than it could've been.)
